Tweet: Violence is inherent in the sex industry only in the same way that criminality is inherent in business in Russia. All private business in Russia was illegal under communism, so when communism fell, the first and strongest entrants were people from criminal backgrounds who had already been engaging in it illegally. They have not yet lost control; not enough time has passed. Tweet: Two of the main reasons people switch to cannabis from pharmaceuticals and other drugs such as alcohol: less side-effects and less withdrawal: "Over 41% state that they use cannabis as a substitute for alcohol, 36.1% use cannabis as a substitute for illicit substances, and 67.8% use cannabis as a substitute for prescription drugs. The three main reasons cited for cannabis-related substitution are 'less withdrawal' (67.7%), 'fewer side-effects' (60.4%), and 'better symptom management' suggesting that many patients may have already identified cannabis as an effective and potentially safer adjunct or alternative to their prescription drug regimen." [Lucas et al. Cannabis as a substitute for alcohol and other drugs: A dispensary-based survey of substitution effect in Canadian medical cannabis patients. Addiction Research & Theory. 2013]

Tweet: I have two serious issues with plug-in cars, local and national. Locally, NH has the highest electric rates in the country (thanks, Seabrook) Nationally, plugging in is a huge waste of energy. To get a gallon of gas worth of electricity out of a wall socket, we need to put at least three gallons into the generator. Every time energy changes state, there is a loss: fuel to heat, heat to steam, steam to mechanical energy, mechanical to electrical, and in the car, electrical to battery, battery to mechanical, mechanical to tires, tires to motion. Add that to transmission losses, and you end up with a lot of waste instead of savings. Plug-in cars will add to the problem, not solve it.
Ans1: ∀x (is an electric car(x) → (has high electric rates(x) ∧ results in energy waste(x) ∧ adds to the problem, not solve it(x))) → opposed
Ans2: ∀x (is electric car(x) → (has issues(x) ∧ wastes energy(x) ∧ adds to problems(x))) → Opposed
Ans3: ∀x (has high electricity rates(x) ∧ has inefficient energy conversion(x)) → is opposed to electric cars(x) → opposed
FOL: ∀x (is an electric car(x) → (has high electric rates(x) ∧ results in energy waste(x) ∧ adds to the problem, not solve it(x))) → opposed

Tweet: Those who privatize access to our shore lines are the first in line for public assistance when floods and hurricanes damage their private refuge. This would be impossible without the publicly funded Corp of Engineers and other public agencies that control river levels through dams and regulations. Tweet: Only Karina Gallardo mentioned automation. The importation of farm laborers will increase our population and only temporarily provide farm laborers. Hopefully, the children of the farm laborers will be educated and find better jobs. The use of imported farm laborers should only be considered a temporary solution. An alternative needs to be sought. This means that a significant amount of money must be allocated to the development of robots to do the picking. Robots have the advantage of being able to sense light outside of the visible range and to be equipped with ultrasonic and other sensors. Tweet: Mike Tyson ate meat when he was the most feared boxer in the world. He only became a vegan long after his boxing days are over, so he hardly counts as an elite vegan athlete. Similarly, Lance Armstrong didn't win all those Tour victories as a vegan. I'd be interested to know when the other athletes Rip mentioned became vegans. I'd bet it was long after they had become champions. In any case, for every vegan elite athlete Rip names, I can name a couple hundred omnivorous ones. So despite these examples, it is entirely possible -- and likely -- that any vegan athlete who reaches elite levels is a fluke and became a champion IN SPITE OF his/her nutritionally deficient vegan diet, and NOT because of it. You can go up a hill by walking on your hands. Doesn't mean it's the best or most efficient way to do it, or even that this is a possibility for most people.

Tweet: "Unlike in the United Arab Emirates, in America we believe parents are capable of making their own decisions about their children's health. We believe in freedom of choice. This freedom of choice extends to when - and even whether- parents vaccinate their kids." Oh really? I seem to remember reading about several recent outbreaks of formerly all but eradicated viruses putting the health and lives of many at risk because of the so called "capable" choices. And this recent choice is rather new. When I was a child back in the 70sI had to get a back-up MMR shot or be denied access to school. What has changed is organized and ill-informed parents pushing back politically to gain exemptions from sound public policy that has protected the American public for generations. Individual choice should not dominate here. We need herd immunity to ensure our society is protected from serious and even fatal diseases. Parents need to be better educated but I don't think we need to continue to allow ever larger groups of children to go without vaccinations - not only for the broader American public but also those children themselves.

A convict is released, put on parole, satisfies the requirements, and is expected to become a normal member of society. But at the same time loses certain right that other citizens have. He/she is in effect no longer a whole citizen, even after having paid satisfied the conditions imposed by the court. So even though his behavior has been corrected he/she is treated as uncorrected. Worse yet, in many cases they can not get certain work, are relegated to the lower levels of society, yet expected to be productive. So what is the purpose of conviction and incarceration? Some may be career criminals, but as we have seen fr to many times, most are not, but in many cases return to crime as that is what they know best. What we see here is a call for permanent retribution, no matter the crime.
Ans1: ∀x ((is a felon(x) ∧ is treated as uncorrected(x) ∧ satisfies the conditions imposed by the court(x)) → is a call for permanent retribution(x)) ∧ (∀x (is a felon(x) → ¬is a career criminal(x) ∧ returns to crime(x))) → opposed
Ans2: ∀x(is a felon(x) ∧ is corrected/rehabilitated(x)) → ¬(faces obstacles after release(x) ∨ 's rights are restricted(x) ∨ faces employment barriers(x)) ∧ 's status should change if goal is rehabilitation(x) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is a felon(x) ∧ has paid their debt to society(x) → ¬has had their rights restricted(x) ∧ ¬is treated as uncorrected(x) ∧ is epected to be productive(x)) → opposed
FOL: ∀x ((is a felon(x) ∧ is corrected/rehabilitated(x)) → ¬(faces obstacles after release(x) ∨ 's rights are restricted(x) ∨ faces employment barriers(x)) ∧ 's status should change if goal is rehabilitation(x) → Support

Tweet: My high school librarian was wonderful. She was at my 50th high school reunion two years ago, no longer able to see, alas, but still the lively, alert, aware person she was years ago. It seems to me that this isn't a question of ebooks replacing paper books as one commenter seems to imply. Nor is it a question of whether or not "internet access" is the same thing, as another comment states. Reading an ebook is a skill, and a different skill from reading a paper book. Using the internet efficiently and critically is also a learned skill. Google and Wikipedia are not the beginning and end. These skills need teaching--skilled teaching. Librarians have the skills to do this, and they have the heart and mission to do this, and they have the love of patrons of the library to do this. So let's not suggest that a visit "once a month or so" is the equivalent of a human being available down the hall daily.
Ans1: ∀x (is a school librarian(x) → (is wonderful(x) ∧ has the skills to teach important skills(x) ∧ has the heart and mission to teach(x) ∧ ¬is equivalent to having a librarian available daily(x))) → support
Ans2: ∃x (is a librarian(x) ∧ teaches skills(x) ∧ has heart and mission(x)) → is supportive of(school librarian) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is a librarian(x) → (is wonderful(x) ∧ has a specific skill(x) ∧ is efficient(x) ∧ has a certain personality(x) ∧ is available daily(x))) → support
FOL: ∃x (is a librarian(x) ∧ teaches skills(x) ∧ has heart and mission(x)) → is supportive of(school librarian) → Support

Tweet: Henri Poincaire, the famous French scientist and mathematician, said, 'Science progresses, funeral by funeral'. evidently, so does common sense, (unless it regresses, election by election) and, as the election debates demonstrate, self-interest trumps rationality when the two are in conflict. Enlightenment is the turning away from self-interest to the larger self, that is, social consciousness and class war is not so much between the haves and have-nots in the financial sense as between the developed and the undeveloped in social consciousness. Such development is typically resisted as the growth of self necessarily invokes a sense of responsibility larger than the self; that is, altruism is seen as a perilous loss of self. Thus, in growth, the self appears exposed, vulnerable and at risk. But as healthcare joins medicare, food stamps, un-employment compensation, social security, the FDIC and soon to be measures to end consumer ripoffs and every sort of unethical capitalism, those who have opposed these measures will be seen to be lacking in common sense. For this reason, Henri and I expect to see the members of the Geriatric Old Party toddle off to oblivion with no one to replace them

Ans2: ∀x (supports measures to protect and help people economically and socially(x) → is seen as lacking common sense(x)) ∧ ∀x (opposes such measures(x) → is seen as lacking common sense(x)) → Support

Tweet: We love taking our kids on vacation to foreign countries. TV and internet are just not adequate substitutes for actually being there to experience another people and culture. They learn to put up with the uncertainties and the unexpected (good or bad) that come with being in an unfamiliar environment. They learn to stay calm, to ask for help, to communicate without speaking the local language, to go with the flow and see what happens. It's great if you can afford it. One thing to keep in mind when planning a trip with kids -- Don't be too ambitious. Don't try to cover 4 cities in a week. The adults will remember the sights, but the kids will remember the frenetic packing and unpacking. So, pick a city and make it your base. Explore that city and stay a while. If you have time, make day trips.

FOL: ∃x (is a family trip(x) ∧ (describes benefits(x) ∧ provides planning tips(x))) → support

Tweet: The title of the article is "Is Immigration Really a Problem?". As is often done, this ignores the fundamental distinction of legality. There are problems that are largely unique to illegal / unregulated immigration including: 1. Job shortage / depressed wages. (Our labor force participation rate is 62.6 compared to 65.7 in Jan 1009) 2. Burden on social welfare system due to illigal immigrants themselves. 3. Burden on social welfare system due to citizens who can not find jobs at acceptable wage levels. 4. Decreased tax collection. 3. No TB screening. 4. No background screening. 5. Discourages wait in line legal immigration. 6. Self selected only. Needs of country not considered. The recent case a a women being shot dead would have been preventable had our immigration laws been followed. Le'ts return to the rule of law with immigration. We can change the laws if we need to but lets start with the President following his oath to the constitution and more specifically that clause requiring him to take care that the laws be faithfully executed. John

Tweet: As a psychologist, I would like to point out that while there are certainly abuses with psychiatric drugs, I see the opposite in my practice. Almost of of my patients vehemently oppose the use of anti-depressants even when they are clearly indicated. I work with them in psychotherapy, but in many cases the results of the therapy (many forms of therapy, including evidenced based cogntive-behavioral, interpersonal, etc) are quite slow, limited, sometimes non-existent, and there is often relapse. In such cases, the ideal treatment is psychotherapy plus antidepressant. The meds help the patient use and retain skills learned in therapy. Both, not one or the other. Also, I usually refer to knowledgeable (and kind) psychiatrist, not general practitions who may not know these drugs very well. The problem is not antidepressants per se, its the improper consumer advertsising, further mis-prescription and monitoring of the drugs, and lack of referral for effective psychotherapy in conjunction with meds.
Ans1: ∀x ((is Prozac(x) ∧ is a psychiatric drug(x)) → (is a treatment(x) ∧ is indicated(x) ∧ is referred(x) ∧ is consumer advertising(x) ∧ is mis-prescribed(x) ∧ is effective psychotherapy(x))) → support
Ans2: ∃x (is Prozac(x) ∧ (has benefits(x) ∧ has appropriate use(x))) → attitude is supportive(x) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is a patient(x) ∧ opposes the use of antidepressants(x) ∧ is indicated for antidepressants(x) ∧ is treated with psychotherapy(x) ∧ ¬is treated with medication (Prozac)(x) ∧ has slow or limited results from therapy(x) ∧ eperiences relapse(x) → receives a combination of psychotherapy and medication(x)) → support
FOL: ∃x (is Prozac(x) ∧ (has benefits(x) ∧ has appropriate use(x))) → attitude is supportive(x) → Support

Tweet: Playing Varsity Lacrosse in college saved me. It was the very best thing I could have done. It kept me focused, gave me a great group of friends, challenged me both physically and mentally, taught me a lot about trust and teamwork and propelled me through school. It was an incredible outlet for my energy and competitive spirt. I still to this day, believe many of my personal and professional strengths were developed by playing sports. The NCAA, without a doubt, needs to change. There is far too much money spent around the NCAA and the culture at top levels can be nasty and unattractive. But that doesn't that mean that Varsity Sports should be cut from colleges and that Varsity athletes should be punished. The NCAA needs reform as a whole-- sports need to be taken off the peddle stool that they currently stand on. But the importance of sports for many shouldn't be forgotten-- it is just as important as the arts and academia. The debate shouldn't be if varsity sports should be cut-- but how to reform the NCAA so that all schools can keep varsity sports without spending so much money.

Tweet: #1, children educated at home turn out to be better socialized than their public schooled counterparts. They are more likely to vote, more likely to get involved in government, and more likely to volunteer for various charitable activities. And, on average, they are better educated. Sending one's children to a public school is on average, the bad decision. While there are good public schools and good public school teachers, there are also countless schools where children do not learn, are not safe (from other students and teachers), and do not get properly socialized. I know this from countless studies and personal experience. My three children, educated at home from birth, are all national merit finalists and prepared to deal with people in the real world because they were in the real world their entire lives, rather than being segregated by age and demographic in a public (aka government compulsory) school. Tweet: Malthusian [mal-thoo-zhuh n, -zee-uh n] Word Origin adjective "Malthusian. Definition: of or relating to the theories of T. R. Malthus, which state that population tends to increase faster, at a geometrical ratio, than the means of subsistence, which increases at an arithmetical ratio, and that this will result in an inadequate supply of the goods supporting life unless war, famine, or disease reduces the population or the increase of population is checked.. . ." Todays Malthusian scholars somehow seem not to be aware that their theories of "overcrowding" were advanced 200 or so years ago by Tom Malthus--and haven't been validated in experience. It matters not that today's scholars cite overproduction of CO2 due to increases in population as the source of the problem, rather than inability to produce a supply of goods adequate to support life.

Tweet: I would imagine that there are also plenty of instances in which a little bit of Internet research winds up improving a person's condition or even saving a life. Nowadays, a quick Google Image search on my mom's part could have convinced him to go much earlier. Doctors deal with people's health all day long and know a lot, but patients and their loved ones are the experts on what is normal for them and are the ones who know when something just doesn't seem right. Tweet: My comprehensive high school sex education course was one of the most valuable to me of all my subjects. My high school classmates and I were the guinea pigs for the pilot program at LSU's University Lab School in 1953. The course was quite comprehensive. It covered the mechanics, contraception, VD, prostitution, deviant sexual behavior. I don't recall the word abstinence being used. However, the teacher, J.Q. Long, emphasized that sex should be more than a physical act with potentially serious consequences, physical and psychological, and was not to be undertaken casually. Twenty-five years later I was amazed when some parents in my children's school in Michigan objected to the sex education courses which I'm pretty sure were less comprehensive than mine thirty years before in Louisiana.

FOL: ∀x (¬(is mentioned(x) ∨ is referenced(x)) → ¬is a kid(x)) → neutral

Tweet: Perhaps the workability of an open-office layout has to do with the age of the workers and the type of business. Internet-focused businesses are staffed with -- and often led by -- just this type of person. Of course people like to have their own offices (status, privacy), but the question is whether having your desk in a communal setting adversly affects one's work production and workplace satisfaction. Tweet: The only concrete definition of royalty I can think of is rule by decree as opposed to rule by consent. Furthermore, it doesn't make any difference if one attains royalty through heredity, voter fraud or simply by buying an election. The result is the same in each case, i.e., the right to rule was gained without the consent of the governed. It must be Bhutan was very lucky because I can't think of any other royal ruler who went down in history as having consistently issued decrees that were in the best interests of those he (or she, in some rare cases) governed. Personally, I would never willingly give up my democratic right to get rid of leaders whose decrees failed this test. We're all human after all and thus everyone is certain to make mistakes eventually. The idea that someone with ultimate power would have the right to make mistakes with no fear that the consequences could result in their removal is, well, beyond reason.
Ans1: ∀x ((is democracy(x) ∧ (issued decrees that were in the best interests of y(x) ∨ could result in the removal of y(x))) → is a system(x)) ∧ (∀x ((issued decrees that were in the best interests of y(x) ∨ is a royal ruler(x)) → ¬could result in the removal of y(x))) ∧ (∀x ((issued decrees that were in the best interests of y(x) ∨ is a royal ruler(x)) → ¬is in the best interests(x)))) ∧ (∀x ((issued decrees that were in the best interests of y(x) ∨ is a royal ruler(x)) → ¬is governed(x)))) ∧ (∀x ((is a royal ruler(x) ∧ went down in history(x)) → (∃y (issued decrees that were in the best interests of y(y, x) ∧ is in the best interests(y))))) ∧ (∀x ((is democracy(x) ∧ is a leader(x)) → (∀y (is a mistake(y) → ¬(is a leader(y) ∧ failed this test(y)))))) ∧ (∀x ((has ultimate power(x) ∧ has the right to make mistakes(x)) → ¬(could result in the removal of y(x, y)) → support
Ans2: ∀x (is democracy(x) → is consent of governed(x)) ∧ is praised(is right to remove leaders(x)) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is a democracy(x) ∧ is gained through consent(x) → ¬is a royalty(x)) → support
FOL: ∀x (is democracy(x) → is consent of governed(x)) ∧ is praised(is right to remove leaders(x)) → Support

Tweet: "I -... - would not support the idea if I doubted our ability to put environmental safeguards in place." Putting "environmental safeguards" in place and preventing disasters are not the same thing. Standard, well intentioned engineering practice in oil production, refining, and transport includes safeguards like double and triple redundant fail safe systems. Still, engineered systems fail and all too recently we've had well-head blowouts (Deep Water Horizon), refinery explosions and fires, and oil transport disasters ranging from pipeline ruptures to tank train derailments to the Exxon Valdez. Imagine a perfect storm situation off Virginia Beach where a well head blowout coincided with a Hurricane Sandy. Crude oil from the Chesapeake to Iceland and a potentially mortal blow to already fragile shore communities and fisheries along the way. The only way to be 100% sure that the East Coast won't suffer catastrophic damage from oil production is to outlaw the outlandishly risky exploitation of hydrocarbons in our salty ocean waters.
Ans1: ∀x (is the Atlantic coast(x) → (could suffer catastrophic damage(x) ∧ is the only way to prevent catastrophic damage(x) ∧ is the risky eploitation of hydrocarbons(x))) → opposed
Ans2: ∃x (poses risks(x) ∧ could cause damage(x) → is prohibited(x)) ∧ y is supportive of y(Atlantic Coast) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is a production of oil(x) ∧ is an environmental concern(x) → is opposed(x)) → opposed
FOL: ∀x (is the Atlantic coast(x) → (could suffer catastrophic damage(x) ∧ is the only way to prevent catastrophic damage(x) ∧ is the risky exploitation of hydrocarbons(x))) → opposed

Tweet: "Are research papers a waste of time?" Absolutely not! The internet may give students and scholars easy access to sources, but many of these sources are flawed or unreliable in some way. Now more than ever, students need to know how to sift through information to find reliable sources and well-constructed arguments. Writing a research paper is still the best way to do this. Select a paper topic that you find interesting or important. Read and evaluate 10-15 reputable sources related to your topic, and then build an argument that engages with and contributes to this existing research. This might not be the most exciting assignment in the world (depends on the topic, I suppose) but it teaches skills that every college graduate should have. Really, every high school graduate ought to have this training as well. But let's not ask for the moon!
Ans1: ∀x (is a research paper(x) → (is essential for developing skills(x) ∧ is necessary for graduates(x))) → support

Ans3: ∀x (is a research paper(x) → (is a skill(x) ∧ is an evaluation(x) ∧ is an argument(x) ∧ is reliable(x))) → support
FOL: ∀x (is a research paper(x) → (is essential for developing skills(x) ∧ is necessary for graduates(x))) → support

Tweet: The author's last sentence actually magpies a strong case for women's colleges. Tweet: I haven't read through all the comments, but I strongly feel that diet (and what keeps one healthy) is extremely individual and dependent on many things-including allergies, sensitivities, previous medical history, religious experience, and emotional situations, to name a few. Tweet: "Casino taxes and development revenue from the city's three casinos generate about $11 million a month for Detroit." And where does this revenue come from? Thin air? The writer has to know this is a negative sum game, not even a zero sum game. For every dollar the city takes in, you can be sure the casino operators take at least five. The people who spend this money are overwhelmingly those who can't afford it, so that the 11 million they get back in services is less than what they lost in the first place. At the end of the day, the casino ends up making no new product, or service, other than escapist entertainment. But, but, but, you say, the casino puts the money back in the community. I bet. See the piece by Professor Simon on Atlantic City. Maybe the money does come out of thin air -- Canadians and non-Detroiters. Well that's great. Here you go, Paul. Sorry, Peter.

Tweet: If we just had millions upon billions living in unindustrialized countries or places in which people had no discretionary income to participate in a consumer society, Erhlich would have remained wrong. But societies around the globe have changed, and everyone desires a higher standard of living. Now Erhlich is right. Okay, let's make an effort to reduce consumption. But does not our economy and our whole way of life rest on the foundation of a consumer society? Without the populace subscribing to and participating in a society dedicated to making or marketing things and buying them, how do we structure society then? What do people do in lieu of buying stuff? How is power accorded and meted out? How do people obtain the necessities? How do they generate income? I would suggest that there is more to the challenge than "to fix capitalism by encouraging innovation in the technologies that can deliver a liveable world. " There will have to be a philosophy with which to address nature and the universe, for both the powers-that-be and hoi polloi.

Tweet: What the NJ Transit employee failed to understand is that there is a distinction between free speech rights (burning a Koran, a flag or what have you) and the fact that employment in America is, by and large, at-will -- you can get fired if your boss doesn't like the color of your socks. If his off-hours -- but very public and very controversial -- actions were deemed to affect his workplace efficiency, then his employer had a perfect right to fire him. Tweet: One of the most important contributions to US education from TFA alumni has not been mentioned by any of the contributors to this discussion. The TFA alumni who leave teaching for other careers retain their knowledge of the real conditions of poor children and their schools. They can and do give voice to those realities in political debates and can counter the many (often willfully) ignorant claims of opponents of public education. Just as Peace Corp volunteers are a source of reality about the Third World, so TFA alumni can and do continue to advocate for poor children and their schools when they become investment bankers, lawyers, or other high earners. Such advocacy doesn't direct benefit the children they taught, but it will benefit public education. TFA recognizes that we need to change the political debate over public education as much as we need to get top graduates into schools as teachers. Rather than harp on the limits of TFA, we should recognize that Wendy Kopp has found a way to move politics in a progressive direction and spend our efforts applying its lessons to other areas of public policy and politics.

Tweet: I just finished seeing a patient after her second attack of pancreatitis over two years. Her most recent attack was uncomplicated and an ultrasound showed a 1.8cm gallstone and multiple small gallstones only in the gallbladder. The bile ducts had no stones and there was not ultrasound abnormality of the pancreas. She had done her internet research and was adamantly convinced that she should never have her gallbladder removed. She somehow learned from the internet that the gallbladder provides necessary vitamins and nutrients and it should not be removed. I am not a gallbladder surgeon and I explained to her how the stones in the gallbladder were the cause of her pancreatitis and the treatment and prevention of more attacks is to electively remove the gallbladder surgically. I explained that drug or diet treatment to dissolve her stones is not usually successful and that there is no absolute need to keep her gallbladder for nutritional reasons. She immediately became defensive and clung even more to her miss-information. I also use the internet to diagnose things. But I stick to ordering replacement parts and fixing household objects.

Tweet: Our drug laws would probably have been liberalized far sooner if we had simply allowed all US citizens to vote including former felons and even those incarcerated. Wrongful convictions, which still happen with far too much frequency in America, would get the extra special attention they deserve if we allowed felons to vote. By disenfranchising this entire group of people, we have created a system that ignores the serious issues related to this population. We have the highest incarceration rate in the world and we disenfranchise millions who are formerly incarcerated because of past mistakes. This process further exacerbates the challenges of ethnic minorities and the working poor. We need to empower all US citizens to be able to participate in our democracy so we can start to create the more equal and fair society we all claim to support.

Tweet: Bove ignores a major factor in largeness, the direction of capital away from productive investment and into speculation. The justification of profitability as a sole measure is a basic one for consolidating banks, but with that consolidation comes direction of capital away from production and into speculative instruments. Irresponsibility came from engineering returns rather than earning them. Failure came from a quantitative analysis of investment options that valued high investment risk over productive risk.In a smaller institution this would have simply constituted fraud. In these behemoths it constitutes lingering catastrophe. We still have not freed capital from these casino operators. We who supply them with deposits and tax buffers are denied a flow of funds in interest or investment than support or employ. Flush them into a banking system that buys us jobs, not chips.

Ans3: ∀x (is in control(x) → (is productive(x) ∧ ¬is speculative(x)) → ¬is irresponsible(x) ∧ ¬is a failure(x)) → Critical → opposed
FOL: ∀x (¬(is mentioned(x) ∨ is referenced(x)) → ¬is control(x)) → neutral

Tweet: I see a procession of overweight, obese, and morbidly obese women in my practice which includes the cure of stress urinary incontinence. I refuse to hitch up the bladder neck of obese women (Body mass index>31) I ask them to lose 30 lbs because 30% will be cured without an operation. I have had a death in my practice because of a pulmonary embolus which is a risk of obesity. A few comply, get their BMI below 31 and I operate if they continue to have a favorable trajectory. I seem to be alone in this practice. One academic told me that if he discriminated against the obese "he could not earn a living (sic!)". I think M.D.'s are mostly in cahoots with the MacDonalds of the world in ignoring the obesity epidemic. I think employers should discriminate but they should start with the CEO of publicly traded corporations and media comentators. Some of the CNBC crowd is overweight. They should slim down and then go after the CEO's by publishing their BMI's. I think the effects on the general population would be rapid.

Ans3: ∀x (is obese(x) → ¬has a high BMI(x)) → opposed
FOL: ∀x (is obesity(x) → (is refused a procedure(x) ∧ is discriminated against(x))) ∧ (is criticized(M.is discriminated against.) ∧ is criticized(employers)) ∧ (is beneficial(general population)) → opposed

Tweet: This comment is a bit dumb in its limited focus. The guy says kids don't need to be taught how to search the internet, as if everything that is available in a library, esp. a research library, can be found on an internet search engine. Not true. There are all kinds of databases with densely packed data that require expertise to access. Helping students find their way through increasingly modern archives of value treasure troves of data is what librarians do. Maybe fifth graders don't all need to do high level research but we need some humans prepared to do serious, in-depth research in the human future. Doesn't that effort begin in school? It is mindboggling me that this 'expert', a high-tech exec in Silicon Valley (as if that means he knows anything about research) who actually participated on a board that established CA educational standards. It's scary to have such a lame-brained mind in such a position of power over educational standards for CA children. I have a doctorate and sometimes I need a librarian to help me find answers to questions. That's what librarians are for. And kids need them more than I do.

Tweet: I have no problem with Happy Hours. I have a huge problem with drunken people in public trying to control a moving vehicle. Tweet: During my career as a college administrator I interviewed my fair share of obese job applicants for professional positions. Regardless of their intellect or job experience, there was no chance of their being hired. Why? Because they couldn't fit in the chairs at the conference table where search committees met. They sat on the edge of chairs and almost fell forward trying to balance, which didn't do much for their concentrating on complex question from faculty members. They were constantly out of breath, and sweating, and struggled to reach for the glass of water set before them. They could barely walk to various sites around campus for a required tour, and in some cases, wouldn't even try. They shuffled down the halls while their fit escorts waited, if not patiently, certainly politely. Faculty and other professional jobs require energy and stamina. No amount of intellect can overcome these kinds of self-induced problems, and discrimination is really irrelevant in such cases when one considers the terrible burden such people impose on employers.
Ans1: ∀x (is an obese job applicant(x) → (is not hired(x) ∧ (has physical limitations(x) ∧ imposes a burden on employers(x)))) → opposed
Ans2: ∀x (is an obese job applicant(x) → (¬is hired(x) ∧ has physical difficulties due to weight(x)) ∧ ¬has energy and stamina required for job(x)) → Opposed
Ans3: ∀x (is obese(x) ∧ is a job applicant(x) → ¬is hired(x)) → opposed
FOL: ∀x (is an obese job applicant(x) → (¬is hired(x) ∧ has physical difficulties due to weight(x) ∧ ¬has energy and stamina required for job(x))) → opposed

Tweet: I know of no small business whose life blood consisted of one or two products developed at high cost wherein those products were not protected by patents or copyrights. Ninety-nine percent of the small business non-competes I have seen try to prevent good salesmen from calling on their customers from the their former employer. The other one percent involved senior executives, were very explicit about the competitive competing firms, and were of sort duration. In most of these cases the employment contract of the hiring company called for the hiring company to defend the executive against legal action by his former employer under the non-compete. So, to come full circle, small business non-competes are almost always aimed at keeping good salesmen in chains.
Ans1: ∀x (is a new employee(x) → is opposed(x)) → opposed

FOL: ∀x(is a new employee(x) ∧ is a good salesman(x) → is opposed(x)) → opposed

Tweet: I agree with others that patient views are not represented here. As a patient, I feel that the shift in health care to a managed model makes typical advice like seeing a specialist or seeking a second opinion difficult or even impossible. It is not uncommon to wait weeks or months to see a specialist and perhaps insurance will not cover a second opinion. It is well and good to advise patients to engage closely with their medical care, but when it is so difficult to see a doctor at all, and then be afforded only a few minutes when you do see them, I can understand why patients might seek out advice elsewhere. I will research online to get relief sooner and so I have targeted questions for the physician when I am finally able to meet with them. This makes a cumbersome process much more productive in my experience.
Ans1: ∀x (is a medical website(x)) → support
Ans2: ∃x (does research(x) ∧ is a medical website(x) ∧ (helps get relief sooner(x) ∨ helps ask better doctor questions(x))) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is a patient(x) ∧ has difficulty seeing a specialist or getting a second opinion(x) ∧ seeks advice online(x) ∧ has a managed healthcare model(x)) → support
FOL: ∃x (does research(x) ∧ is a medical website(x) ∧ (helps get relief sooner(x) ∨ helps ask better doctor questions(x))) → Support

Tweet: I check out the Mayo Clinic and the NIH when I want general information. Many of us do. It has helped me determine that I didn't need treatment for subconjunctival hemorrhage, but that my daughter probably had pneumonia after a serious viral infection, and needed treatment. Using a website to substitute for knowledge that takes a physician a minimum of ten years to acquire is nuts. Using a website to gain general information is not. I know the adage - " A little learning is a dangerous thing" - but no knowledge is pretty dangerous too. Adjust to the era. Information is out there. Support efforts to teach people how to use it.

Tweet: I am a doctor and am at a distinct advantage in terms of understanding what my doctor is trying to tell me when I am a patient. So, while Dr. Google and his message boards are not a substitute for my medical education, experience and expertise (and must always come with that disclaimer), he does serve a role in terms of patient education and helping one to cope that I may not be able to provide given the time limitations of my job.

Tweet: My pursuit of my 'right weight' also includes a daily cardio & weightlifting routine, cycling (18-20 miles a trip), hiking (6-10 miles) and the like when I'm not in the gym, visits with my physician, a nutritionist (confirming my already stellar diet) and an endocrinologist. And here I sit still, @ a 35 BMI. There are nights I've cried myself to sleep, exhausted and sore while my body mocks my attempts to reach my 'right' BMI. Tweet: This passes for logic at the Cato Institute? I guess it does since the last statement is rather limited, "Thus, the electric car is not a cost effective answer to all our problems and would not exist without government tax subsidies." It is not cost effective now. Our crazy-low gas prices are the result of decades of subsidies, not to mention a few wars and environmental costs. Was the light bulb cost effective the first month out? How about the personal computer? Remember the early ones with 250MB hard drives and those gigantic floppies? Things get going, not because they save money right out of the gate, but rather because people see potential in what they may become. Even cranky-pants Cato knew enough Aristotle to understand the subtle relationship between potential and actual.

Tweet: I used to teach Quantitative Reasoning. One of the databases we used to analyze was birth rate by country. That was over ten years ago, but it showed my students how high birth rates would become unsustainable in small countries without similar economic growth rates. The same countries we identified as problems back in that course are in the center of the refugee and problematic youth crises now. Just divide the birth rate (in percentage) into 70 and you get the population doubling time. How can an economically stressed country every imagine handling the doubling of its population in less than a generation? It doesn't make any sense to talk about overall wealth in the world, either, when people have no realistic prospect of any future access to it without migrating. I would try migrating too if I were in such a country.

Ans2: ∀x ((has high birth rate(x) ∧ is small country(x) ∧ ¬has economic growth(x)) → (is unsustainable(x) ∧ causes overcrowding(x))) ∧ (causes overcrowding(x) → is source of refugee crisis(x)) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (has a high birth rate(x) ∧ ¬has economic growth(x) → ¬is sustainable(x) ∧ is overcrowding(x)) → Concerned → opposed
FOL: ∀x ((has high birth rate(x) ∧ is small country(x) ∧ ¬has economic growth(x)) → (is unsustainable(x) ∧ causes overcrowding(x))) ∧ (causes overcrowding(x) → is source of refugee crisis(x)) → Support

Tweet: The thesis of the intro to this debate is that essays somehow free up students' thinking while the rigidity of term papers is stultifying. It's been a long time since high school and college, but I believe that all term papers begin with a thesis, much like this debate did. And the goal of a term paper is to rigorously examine all evidence supporting and conflicting with that thesis to test its validity. An essay simply puts forth a thesis and allows for a highly selective examination of evidence to support it. I truly believe the rigor of the former is essential in essential to training young minds to think clearly. Perhaps if the Tea Party members had been called upon to write term papers on economics, the nation would have preserved its credit rating and avoided our second slow-down. They would have been incapable of supporting their fiction that giving tax breaks to billionaires uplifts people the 25% of this nation who are underemployed or out of work.

Ans3: ∀x (is a term paper(x) → supports the author's claim(x)) → support
FOL: ∀x ((is a term paper(x) → is rigorous(x)) ∧ (is an essay(x) → allows for a selective examination of evidence(x))) → support

Tweet: Of course individuals with dual citizenship can be model citizens, that is until the policies of their two countries conflict. Those things don't normally happen for most people, unless they work for the government. My wife had dual citizenship, but when she began working for the U.S. Department of State she was asked to renounce the non-US one in order to get a security clearance. Back in my military career, it was common for foreign nationals to enlist, but hey did not get a Secret clearance until they became U.S. citizens and renounced their birth citizenship. That clearance was critical to becoming a non-commissioned officer or commissioned officer. Maybe the Congresswoman found out she would also lose her clearance if she kept here non-US citizenship, and that would put her seat on the House Select Committee on Intelligence in question. Just guessing there, but I wouldn't want anyone with dual citizenship - and therefore assumed dual allegiances - on any Congressional oversight committee, especially one with access to U.S. national security intelligence. Not saying the Swiss are our enemies, but I'd like a hard line drawn that is the same for the Congressional hierarchy and us lowerachy.

Tweet: Local schools are financed almost exclusively without federal tax dollars. Therefore it does not make sense to offer a tax credit for home schooling from federal income taxes. If individual states or local governments want to offer tax credits or other incentives for home schooling, that would be appropriate, since it is mostly from state income or local property taxes that most schools are funded. In my opinion, though, they shouldn't. If you offer tax credits to home schooling parents, surely you will also want to offer tax credits to parents of private school students, and families with no school age children too, for that matter. By the time you are done, you don't have tax credits any more, you essentially have an additional tax paid only by families with children enrolled in public schools. Tweet: Some of my best students--bright, knowledgeable, committed--wanted to teach for America. I advised them against it. They did not have experience. Schools deserve the best teachers possible, especially in challenging schools. Being a good and effective teacher requires years of training and then continuing education,, not just in one's subject, but also in pedagogy, didactics, classroom management, organization, etc. Other countries train teachers much better and longer: they have years of specialized course work and then up to two years of assistant teaching. It pays off. Like the structural inequality that finances schools through property taxes, teacher training in the US is vastly uneven and thus perpetuates social inequality and hinders economic progress. We need uniform standards across states, equal funding for all schools, and a better education for educators.

Tweet: When I observe that admission standards and courses in "college" leading to a BA have slipped to a level sometimes lower than a good suburban high school in the 1960's I shudder. 1. Our K12 education could contain a much higher level core curriculum and fostering of critical thinking and self learning BEFORE high school graduation. Of course, the students would have to be willing to actually perform and not all would get into the upper 10% of the graduating class, but the general level of graduates would return to something substantial. 2. Post secondary training and "college" need not be the same thing. In Europe there are post secondary opportunities to learn trades, many business skills, even things like working in the travel industry(think hotel management, package travel planning) 3. Diluting something like the standards of a university system to allow for more and more "remedial cases" is not doing anyone a favor. Offer post high school training at a multitude of levels. 4. Expect more from industry than just "we want workers ready to start tomorrow" - bring back the training programs and apprenticeship programs that build good and loyal workforces.

Tweet: I can have all sorts of long and short term capital gains within my regular IRA and tax rates on them are bupkis until I either roll over money to a Roth or withdraw from my IRA - which money (including gains) is then taxed like regular income. Conversely, gains in a mature Roth IRA aren't taxed when I eventually draw down from that account. Personally I would protect capital gains, dividends and interest held in retirement accounts from any taxation - and tax those outside IRAs and 401Ks at regular income rates. Interest earned on FDIC protected savings accounts of $250K or under (the account balance, NOT $250K in interest) should also be exempt, and above that fully taxable. This would protect middle class savers should they ever actually see interest beyond pennies in their accounts.

Tweet: It gets worse - far worse - for those people who make deliveries. It is extremely hard - if not impossible - to convey to a customer that a "delivery charge" is not a tip, especially when the vendors used to promise "free delivery". Greedy shop operators take their cut off the top. Drivers need to be paid for the use of their vehicles but often do not get enough from the owners to defray those costs. Often, too, the delivery people get compensated at the same paltry rates as inside wait staff - with the implicit inclusion of a certain gratuity amount to even meet the minimum wage.. An educated consumer will ask: "Does the delivery charge include your gratuity and the costs you incurred using your vehicle to get here?" An educated consumer should be anyone who orders any food to be delivered to his door. An educated consumer should be empathetic to the person who hands him his food at the door and, consequently tip as much as he can.

Tweet: Patients consult the internet out of desperation, because they've gotten no help from doctors who spend 5 minutes with them before moving on to the next patient. I've seen it over and over in my own family: A parent with late onset Type 1 diabetes who spent 2 years in the ER with glucose readings well over 400, because doctors would not acknowledge that a thin, active 68-year old might possibly have Type 1 requiring insulin instead of Type 2. A sibling with thyroid disease and a huge goiter whose doctor dismissed it until it finally became toxic. Another with a chronically ruptured appendix who kept being sent home from the ER with ludicrous diagnoses, until it finally became septic, resulting in 2 weeks in the ICU. We diagnosed all these conditions ourselves, before the doctors did. It actually didn't get us any help, because doctors really don't like being challenged. But when your loved one is dying before your eyes and getting no help, what else are you supposed to do?

Tweet: I'm a psychiatrist on the faculty of Johns Hopkins University, and although I now specialize in dementia I used to work heavily in addictions and chronic mental illness. Drugs of abuse and addiction tend to move in fads, fashions, and trends, and it is important for public health that doctors' training adjust to these constant changes. At this moment the trend is opioid addiction particularly prescription drugs. The trend is moving a bit back to heroin (because it's cheaper!) but prescription drug addiction is still a huge public health problem. We (doctors) created the problem (inadvertently) and we should help solve it. A brief web-based training is not too much to ask; for many doctors it will be redundant as is much of the ongoing training we are required to participate in; but it is important to spread the word widely in the medical community.

Tweet: Many TFA folks are feeling defensive these days, and rightly so. The program promises more than it can deliver. It is not the fault of these idealistic and/or ambitious young people that the program has been overly touted as the silver bullet for all education's problems. There is nothing wrong with leaving education after two years, becoming an administrator or going to law school. The problem is that attrition is basically a design feature of the program. An unprepared teacher in a high needs classroom will burn out in two years. I almost did, until I realized that I needed to set boundaries and have a life. The problem is that students pay by losing energetic teachers every year, would-be teachers are discouraged and leave the classroom, and the taxpayers are footing too much of the bill for a program with questionable returns. There needs to be an overhaul if the public is to be expected to continue supporting a program that is not successful in helping create long term stability in schools.
Ans1: ∀x (is TFA(x) → (promises more than it can deliver(x) ∧ has attrition as a design feature(x) ∧ negatively affects students, potential teachers, and tapayers(x) ∧ needs an overhaul for long-term stability(x))) → opposed
Ans2: ∀x ((is TFA(x) → (promises more than it can deliver(x) ∧ has attrition as a design feature(x) ∧ leaves unprepared teachers who burn out(x) ∧ hurts students(x) ∧ has questionable returns(x))) ∧ (needs an overhaul(x))) → Opposed
Ans3: ∀x (is TFA(x) ∧ is overhyped(x) ∧ leads to burnout(x) ∧ causes attrition(x) ∧ has questionable returns(x)) → Critical → opposed
FOL: ∀x ((is TFA(x) → (promises more than it can deliver(x) ∧ has attrition as a design feature(x) ∧ negatively affects students, potential teachers, and taxpayers(x) ∧ needs an overhaul for long-term stability(x))) → opposed

Tweet: I will go to Sushi Yasuda now just because they have this policy. Tipping is an annoying and outdated American custom. Frankly, I'm surprised servers are so up in arms about it. Particularly in a recession state, having a predictable salary would be more of an ideal state, rather than relying on the generosity of its patrons. As restaurants continue to increase the price of food and drinks, tipping will indeed suffer. Either lower the cost of meals, and leave tipping in place - or - keep prices as is and offer salary. I'm not thrilled that a meal for 2 in NY (with app, entrees, and drinks) can be as much as $100 at mid-range places. A tip is to congratulate a job well done. Not because you simply take my order and bring food. You have to exceed expectations / work for my money. Don't like the industry you are in or unsatisfied with the low wage, then you should do something about it and don't expect me and other patrons to reward you.
Ans1: ∀x ((is the workplace(x) ∧ has a tipping policy(x)) → (is dissatisfied with relying on the generosity of patrons(x) ∧ wants a predictable salary(x) ∧ ¬(is a patron(x) → rewards the servers(x)))) → opposed
Ans2: ∃x(is a workplace(x) ∧ (is a salary(x) → ¬is tip-based(x))) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (has a tipping policy(x) ∧ has a predictable salary(x) ∧ has high prices(x) → ¬is a workplace(x)) → neutral
FOL: ∀x ((is the workplace(x) ∧ has a tipping policy(x)) → (is dissatisfied with relying on the generosity of patrons(x) ∧ wants a predictable salary(x) ∧ ¬(is a patron(x) → rewards the servers(x)))) → opposed

Tweet: Employees should be free to move or sell their talents to the highest bidder. A time restricted none compete that's enforced through compensation by the former employer who wishes to restrict the employee seems like reasonable protection for both sides. The employee can't work for a year or two in their most lucrative field but the employer who wishes to restrict them pays them a portion of their lost wages for the period of enforcement. A free market for goods and services includes labor. A none compete does more than protect intellectual property it suppresses wages and creates a sense that the employee is property of the employer if they wish to stay in the field were they have the most experience and potential value.

Tweet: Doctors, in my numerous recent experiences caring for myself and my family, don't often spend much time talking with patients, so I've had to look things up online. I'd rather talk to a doctor with appropriate expertise and knowledge of our specific details. But we get rushed out of the office, usually after a long wait in reception, with just a prescription-- or an appointment for tests or surgery-- in hand. I've found that veterinarians are much more willing to talk; vets have told me about complications to watch for, they've compassionately explained what to expect about the progression of disease and they've offered suggestions for how to cope with the inconvenience and indignities of aging and illness. I respect M.D.s and D.V.M.s-- but I think medical doctors can learn a lot from vets.

FOL: ∀x ((¬is mentioned(x) ∧ ¬is referenced(x)) ∧ (relates to looking online(x) → is neutral(x))) → Neutral

Tweet: All six commentators make valid points. But I'm struck by the fact that none of them discuss the injustice of human beings monopolizing so large a percentage of Earth's habitat and resources, or the resulting ongoing mass extinction of Earth's species. If a particular nation or people were aggressively displacing other nations and peoples, overrunning their land and taking their resources, leaving these others displaced, diminished, even completely exterminated, the world would have no problem calling this behavior by its proper name: genocidal warfare. Its time we ended our war on nature and accepted limits to human numbers and human economic demands.

Tweet: If the function is a basic governmental function, the job surely can be done most economically with direct government supervision of the employees doing the job. With privatization there is profit and the overhead of having goverment agents doing the contracting and overseeing the contract. When the Ohio governor wants to sell publicly-owned prisons to private contractors and says that then they become profitable, it says to me that the governor's thinking is not working well. Who pays the bill to the private contractor? -- the government! Plus some profit, and the overhead of competing the contract and overseeing that the contract is being properly carried out!! Also, contracting out jobs opens the door for politicians giving the contracts to favorites. Civil service regulations prohibits some corruption with direct government employees.

Tweet: I wasn't aware that Justice Ginsburg automatically surrendered her basic Constitutional rights when she joined the Supreme Court, just as I wasn't aware that President Obama automatically surrendered some of his prerogatives during the final year of his second term simply because it is the final year. I keep looking in the Constitution for the relevant Article or Amendment that declares it so, but fail to find it. Perhaps my research techniques are deficient in some way. Perhaps Sen. McConnell or another Republican political theologian could appraise me of my errors of my ways. Why do Republican Senators believe themselves entitled to re-design the American political system, especially how it works to better suit their partisan purposes while out of power? And why do they justify their institutional encroachments by offering entirely new interpretations of the Constitution that were neither envisioned nor adopted by the Framers nor debated and ratified by Congress and the States? Are those better questions for Professor Gillers to ponder than whether Justice Ginsburg spoke out of turn, or whether her desire not to play mute swan in a golf course pond offends tender Republican sensitivities.

Tweet: Not dumber. But definitely leaving behind much of the education that makes life and conversation with others fascinating. Business majors may avoid fine arts, literature, language and history. Those aspects of education are handy when dealing with people of other cultures. If politicians during the Bush push for war had had even conversations with journalists in the Middle East for a decade or more, they may have had some grasp of the enormous tribal and religious ties therein, and perhaps have not proceeded so. The society of the nineteenth and twentieth century was fostered by education that was broad and deep. By the 1990's and later, music and art were narrowing and the ability to discriminate what was good was replaced by what was accepted. We are dropping old attitudes and replacing them with fashion. The ability to discern and choose what is good is set aside for the rush to be considered aware and clever, and worse, cool.

Tweet: Contrary to Fulsom's assertion that agricultural subsidies arrived in the present in a time capsule sealed by FDR himself, the truth is that most modern agricultural subsidy programs were heavily re-engineered into their current states during the Nixon administration by Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz. His mantra to farmers--"get big or get out"--may or may not have been a direct political response to rising food prices in the early 1970s, but the fact remains that it incentivized the rise of the massive agribusiness and the modern era of industrial agriculture. The irony that Fulsom fails to mention is that modern industrial agriculture in the US is not tooled to survive and thrive without these subsidies. If subsidies are to be eliminated--which I hope to see--the US will need to shift its agricultural paradigm away from industrially grown monoculture.
Ans1: ∀x ((is a subsidy(x) ∧ was re-engineered(x)) → incentivized the rise of agribusiness and industrial agriculture(x)) ∧ (is a political response(x) → needs to be eliminated(x)) ∧ needs to be eliminated(x) → needs to shift away from industrially grown monoculture(x) → opposed
Ans2: ∃x(is a subsidy(x) ∧ is agriculture(x) ∧ (incentivizes industrialization(x) ∨ is necessary for survival(x))) → Neutral
Ans3: ∀x (was re-engineered during the Nion administration(x) ∧ incentivizes the rise of massive agribusiness and industrial agriculture(x) ∧ is not sustainable without subsidies(x) → ¬is an agricultural subsidy program(x)) → opposed
FOL: ∀x ((is a subsidy(x) ∧ was re-engineered(x)) → incentivized the rise of agribusiness and industrial agriculture(x)) ∧ (is a political response(x) → needs to be eliminated(x)) ∧ needs to be eliminated(x) → needs to shift away from industrially grown monoculture(x) → opposed

Tweet: As the 61 year old parent of two late 20 year olds I think all the helicopter parents here who think they can monitor their kids to the nth degree and not destroy the relationship are out of their minds. Tweet: I adopted at 40 and have no regrets. But I do wish sometimes that I had the strength I used to have a decade back. Tweet: One need not read any of these articles to know the answer to the question, "should those with beach front homes have to open their land to the public?" because the answer is an emphatic no. Tweet: I agree that parents (and the kids, once they're old enough--say, 16) should have the right to opt in or out of SOME vaccinations--namely, ones for diseases that are hard to spread. Hepatitis B? HPV? Be my guest--that choice only affects your family, because those are not diseases your kid can spread at school, on the bus, etc. But no one without a medical exemption should be able to opt out of vaccinations against HIGHLY CONTAGIOUS, very dangerous diseases like German measles, pertussis/whooping cough, mumps (which can leave little boys permanently infertile), etc. Measles can live on surfaces like classroom desks and the metal handles people hold in buses for several hours. Nobody has the right to expose complete strangers to devastating diseases that are so easy to prevent.

I would have appreciated more time to make sure I understand what the results mean versus feeling like I got brushed off. This is the reason that I use Dr. Google... not enough time from my doctor.

Tweet: Contrary to popular belief, there is no mandatory voting in Australia. Adults are required to attend a polling station, to produce identification, and to have their name crossed off the electoral roll. They are then handed voting slips but there is no requirement to fill them out or submit them, or to submit a valid vote. This system ensures that no-one is forced to vote if they do not wish to, but also ensures that the barriers to participation are removed. It embodies the Australian ethos of "a fair go for all". Sadly I don't think the system used here in the USA is worthy of its citizens.
Ans1: ∀x ((¬is mandatory(x) ∧ removes barriers to participation(x)) ∧ (is praised(x) ∧ is contrasted(x) ∧ is used in the USA(x) → is worthy of its citizens(x))) → support
Ans2: ∃x(is voting(x) ∧ ¬requires participation(x) ∧ ¬has barriers(x) ∧ is worthy of citizens(x)) ∧ ¬is worthy of citizens(US voting system) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is an adult in Australia(x) → (is required to attend a polling station(x) ∧ is required to produce identification(x) ∧ has their name crossed off the electoral roll(x) ∧ is handed voting slips(x))) → support
FOL: ∀x ((¬is mandatory(x) ∧ removes barriers to participation(x)) ∧ (is praised(x) ∧ is contrasted(x) ∧ is used in the USA(x) → is worthy of its citizens(x))) → support

Tweet: The racial argument is a distraction: relevant to the repudiation of other policies but not this one. The real question is whether our right to vote should be linked to compliance to law. I suggest that a due process argument applies. While criminals were sentenced under due process, the removal of voting rights was attached not by the court but by the legislature without reference to the particular case. If illegal action is thus punished, should we include traffic offenses? Late filing of taxes? Disenfranchisement seem an unusual and arbitrary punishment and is not handled by the judiciary to whom the constitution gave the authority in sentencing. Star Ship Troopers was a dreadful, great movie: but it held that the right to vote was earned by military service. In America, the right is not explicitly defined but I suggest that it is implicitly based on citizenship and felons remain citizens. You may not like that they can vote, but that should hold no greater weight that your dislike of that idiot down the street with all those dumb signs in his yard.
Ans1: ∀x (is a felon(x) → has the right to vote(x)) ∧ suggests that felons should retain their right to vote(x) → support
Ans2: ∀x (is a citizen(x) ∧ is a felon(x)) → can vote(x) ∧ ¬∀x(is a felon(x) → (had due process(x) ∧ 's punishment was proper(x))) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (¬(is a felon(x) ∨ has the right to vote(x)) → ¬is linked to compliance with the law(x)) → neutral
FOL: ∀x (is a felon(x) → has the right to vote(x)) ∧ suggests that felons should retain their right to vote(x) → support

Tweet: As a cancer survivor (14 years in remission after an aggressive lymphoma treated with Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibody therapy) I am happy to say that I made very extensive use of the Google during my treatment. It obviously doesn't replace or 'outrank' my specialists, but I found it was a big help in educating me and filling in background info on my situation and the treatment options that were being recommended. I believe researching options online helped me to ask better questions and ultimately made me a lot more comfortable with the treatment plan my doctors recommended. In most cases, the information I found online agreed with what the docs were telling me. I found that to be very comforting because I didn't just feel like I was taking everything the docs said on blind faith and at face value. In at least 2 cases, the questions I asked did lead to changes in my treatment plan.
Ans1: ∀x (is a medical website(x) → (is useful(x) ∧ aligns with doctors' recommendations(x) ∧ leads to changes in treatment plan(x))) → support
Ans2: ∀x ((is a medical website(x) → (helps educate(x) ∧ allows better questions(x) ∧ makes one comfortable with doctor's plan(x) ∧ agrees with doctor's information(x)))) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is a medical website(x) → (provides helpful information(x) ∧ supports patient education(x))) → support
FOL: ∀x ((is a medical website(x) → (is useful(x) ∧ aligns with doctors' recommendations(x) ∧ leads to changes in treatment plan(x) ∧ helps educate(x) ∧ allows better questions(x) ∧ makes one comfortable with doctor's plan(x) ∧ agrees with doctor's information(x) ∧ provides helpful information(x) ∧ supports patient education(x)))) → support

Tweet: I am a NYC teacher who has taught in public, charter and now private school. My two children attend a gifted and talented public school and private school. Tweet: Non-compete clauses are not about protecting proprietary information. That can be done with non-disclosure agreements. What they're really about is inhibiting the free market for labor. Employers use non-compete clauses to discourage employees from leaving. That saves the employer the cost and trouble of training a new worker, and it keeps wages down by restricting the employee's ability to leave if he or she does not get a raise. Non-compete clauses should be banned as a simple matter of fairness, and because competition for labor makes companies better.
Ans1: ∀x ((is a new employee(x) → (is discouraged from leaving(x) ∧ saves costs(x) ∧ keeps wages down(x))) ∧ (should be banned(x) ∧ is fair(x) ∧ promotes competition for labor(x))) → opposed
Ans2: ∀x (is a new employee(x) → causes costs to train(x)) ∧ (leaves current employer(x) ∧ finds new job opportunities(x) → ¬is a new employee(x)) → Opposed
Ans3: ∀x (has a non-compete clause(x) → ¬is a new employee(x)) → neutral
FOL: ∀x ((is a new employee(x) → (is discouraged from leaving(x) ∧ saves costs(x) ∧ keeps wages down(x))) ∧ (should be banned(x) ∧ is fair(x) ∧ promotes competition for labor(x))) → opposed

Tweet: I look up symptoms on the internet with the aim of discovering whether or not I need to see a doctor and if there is anything non-invasive I can do for myself either instead or in the meantime. Tweet: The farm subsidies actually hurt the type of farm that has traditionally been the backbone of America. I refer to the small to medium size family farm. Tweet: The US is becoming more and more like a military campground. I live in Vancouver, a short distance from the US-Canada border, supposedly a "friendly' border. It's not friendly at all. Tweet: The banks made deliberate decisions that they correctly believed would increase their profits immensely if nothing blew up on them and would increase their profits moderately if they were caught and had to pay modest fines. No matter what they did, the banks and their management would make out like successful bandits while others would suffer. Reforms have not appeared to change the dynamics because the reforms that are politically feasible to the vast majority of the legislators taking contributions from the banks are ones that are acceptable to the banks. I expect until there is personal responsibility by the bank management all the incentives are toward risky behavior. Under these conditions, I don't see how a bank that didn't engage in risky behavior could compete. Nationalizing banks would make it clearer than ever that the banks were too big to fail (and could engage in even more risky behavior on more profitable terms than their competitors who lacked the too big to fail guarantee)

Tweet: "Think about it. The idea that waiters are such lazy idiots that the only thing keeping them doing a good job is the immediate gratification of cash in their hand at the end of service is kind of insulting. They are people just like your accountants, IT staff, etc. They can see the benefit of working hard and at the end of the week getting a predictable paycheck and maybe even -gasp!- health insurance. Yes, eliminating tipping would only work if the structure of restaurant staff and compensation was rethought. Tweet: I'd like to know where Dr. Evins is getting her statistics. They contradict virtually everything I've read about marijuana, and they contradict my personal experience. I smoked marijuana from August 1972 to November 1973, at first fairly rarely, eventually nearly daily, for a few weeks twice daily, then abruptly stopped completely for about two months, then smoked a few times a week for a couple months. I haven't smoked in since. These changes in usage had to do with availability and (mostly) social circumstances. (I didn't begin to crave it more; I gradually lost interest as the novelty wore off.) Marijuana in those days was very much a social drug; I smoked it alone just once in my life. I wouldn't even say that stopping and starting was easy; it was nothing whatsoever. I never encountered anyone at any time in my life who showed the slightest sign of being even slightly addicted. (I do know what addiction is. I've known many people, some of them close to me, clearly addicted to alcohol.) It's true, however, that marijuana does cause "like memory and cognitive impairment"--TEMPORARILY. It's called "being stoned".
Ans1: ∀x ((is marijuana(x) ∧ contradicts the author's knowledge and personal eperience(x)) ∨ (is marijuana(x) ∧ is addictive(x)) ∨ (is marijuana(x) ∧ causes memory and cognitive impairment(x))) → is opposed(x) → opposed

Ans3: ∀x (¬(is smoked(x) ∧ is addictive(x)) ∧ ¬(is smoked(x) ∧ causes cognitive impairment(x)) ∧ ¬(is smoked(x) ∧ is temporary(x))) → neutral
FOL: ∀x ((is marijuana(x) ∧ contradicts the author's knowledge and personal experience(x)) ∨ (is marijuana(x) ∧ is addictive(x)) ∨ (is marijuana(x) ∧ causes memory and cognitive impairment(x))) → is opposed(x) → opposed

Tweet: The critics of this plan are arguing that a ratings system will hurt the people college is supposed to help most: low income, poorly prepared students. I would argue that the university system as it exists already hurts these people. My husband teaches at the University of New Orleans, where much of the student population comes from the underserved and woefully inadequate Louisiana state public education system. Although he works in a production department, he teaches history and theory, requiring his students to research and write thousands of words a semester. Even though they are juniors and seniors, most of his students don't know how to do this, so he conducts writing and research seminars for every class, every semester. Students fear his class before they take it, yet he has the highest approval rating in his department, which is one of the highest rated at the university. Despite his exemplary record teaching poorly prepared students, he was denied tenure because his publication record wasn't strong. They told him that for his position, publication was THE top priority. A university that claims to value its students actually had the gall to put this in writing.

Tweet: In 2013, the American Medical Association's 527-member House of Delegates revised the AMA's position, in place since 1977, that urged "modification of state law to reduce the severity of penalties for possession of marijuana." Of course, the US government blithely ignored this advice ever since it was given and went on to arrest over thirty million citizens for possession. The AMA delegates also endorsed a review of the "risks and benefits" of new legal markets in Colorado and Washington. One of those "benefits" is readily apparent - an average of 714 people per month were arrested in Colorado for possession in the first nine months of 2012. Arrest numbers have dropped over 80% in Colorado since legalization. Every person not arrested is a tragedy avoided. Many argue for a "go slow" approach to legalization - exactly what we've seen for decades. The American Medical Association should speak forcefully of the health dangers of incarceration, the psychological damage of being arrested and incarcerated, and on behalf of the millions who would benefit from cannabis as medicine.

FOL: ∃x (is positive impact(x) ∧ is reduced/dropped(x) ∧ is Colorado(x)) → Support

Tweet: My wife and I married at 24. We waited and had our first son at 31. It took 5 years to have a second although we wanted our kids 2 years apart. The energy of the young mothers put us to shame. We waited for the usual economic reasons although my wife was looking at nursery furniture and prams at 26. My son was born 2 weeks after I was admitted to the NY Bar. Now I have two fine sons., 48 and 43. They are good, smart, funny and loving sons and arrow straight. Total product: one intelligent and beautiful grand daughter now entering college. I have lived a very long time and I don't have many regrets but the biggest regret is waiting too long to have children and maybe to have had 3 instead of 2. My wife so much wanted a daughter. A grand daughter helps. Yet we will not dance at her wedding and see her children.

Tweet: The author here misses the point. Marijuana is massively more popular than any other drug, with something like 1 in three Americans admit to having tried it at least once. Heroin is more like 1 in 100. The way this actually works is: Most people try Marijuana before anything else. The vast majority of them do not go on to anything else, but of those who do, Marijuana preceded. By analogy - riding motorcycles is very dangerous and relatively few people do it. Bicycle riding us much easier and safer, and most people ride a bicycle before they get on a motorcycle. Does it make sense to ban bicycles in order to prevent the harms of motorcycle riding? The problem here is that the correlation goes the other way. Being a habitual Heroin user makes it more likely that you've used Marijuana. That doesn't mean that smoking Marijuana makes you more likely to go on to harder drugs. Ask how many of your friends who smoke Marijuana have ever done Heroin. The answer is tiny. This man has an M.D. and should know better than spreading this disinformation.
Ans1: ∀x ((is marijuana(x) ∧ is popular(x)) ∧ (¬(is marijuana(x) → (is heroin(x) ∨ leads to using harder drugs(x)))) ∧ (¬(is banned(x) → causes harm(x)))) ∧ ¬spreads misinformation(x) → support
Ans2: ∀x (is marijuana(x) → is popular(x)) ∧ ¬(is marijuana(x) → is a gateway drug(x)) ∧ (is heroin(x) → is marijuana(x)) → Support
Ans3: ∀x (is popular(x) → ¬is dangerous(x)) → support
FOL: ∀x ((is marijuana(x) ∧ is popular(x)) ∧ (¬(is marijuana(x) → (is heroin(x) ∨ leads to using harder drugs(x)))) ∧ (¬(is banned(x) → causes harm(x)))) ∧ ¬spreads misinformation(x) → support

Tweet: What a silly line of reasoning. We have to stop thinking about immigrants as people who simply take our stuff, as if there were a finite supply of "jobs" piled up in a warehouse somewhere, the distribution of which is a zero-sum exercise. Immigrants are people and people are assets; they bring their creativity, energy, and culture to America for everyone's benefit. If that needs to be stated in terms one can measure with a dollar value, think of immigrants as sources of customer demand, stimulating employment. Immigrant-run restaurants and shops are a perfect example. Would native-born Americans be working at Chinese restaurants or Mexican bakeries if not for immigration? No, because those businesses wouldn't exist in the first place, and we'd all be worse off as a result. If those who call for America to exclude immigrants get their wish, the immigrants will benefit some other country, at which point these same pundits will predictably get their pants in a twist because "Country X is beating us" in education, employment, creativity, etc.

Tweet: The debate seems limited to certain medical websites. What really gives good options is the reading of research articles themselves. Read Swiss, Italian, Armenia, Turksih researchers!

Tweet: President Obama received a Nobel Prize for Peace because so many influential people were so convinced that he would pursue peace by resolving the nexus of antagonism that separates the Muslim and Judeo-Christian worlds ... by ending the policy of making Palestinians pay for what Germans did to Jews during World War II. Tweet: A great article. Tweet: My daughter would LOVE to be able to opt in and out of classes at the Virginia public high school she attends. Personally, I would LOVE to be able to pull her out of certain classes and get her tutored in them or some such. But that's now how it works. If her high school is not good enough for these kids to attend, then they have no business being there playing sports. It is not a cafeteria, you don't get to pick and choose what you do and do take off the tray. Why don't we just take team sports out of the schools and make them a separate institution? Certainly a lot of the folks who are gung ho on their local high school football and basketball programs don't give much of a damn about the academics of those students anyway so long as they can have a winning team. Let's set up something elsewhere and let the rest of our kids concentrate on getting an education that will enable them to do something besides playing sports!

Tweet: It's sad an ludicrous that this should even be open to debate...all citizens have the right to an equal education in order to have some chance at equal opportunity, and it seems pretty obvious that schools for the deaf are essential to giving them equal opportunity. Tweet: Regardless of what other commenters think about Palestine and the Palestinians- some of it blatantly racist e.g. that Arabs are a violent people and therefore not worthy of U.S. support, some of it just historically ignorant- e.g. Arafat turned down a peace deal and therefore Palestinians are undeserving of a state forever after - the issue isn't Palestine v.
